utterances.utterance: Good evening. This is the 5 p.m. Eastern Time update on Hurricane Florence. Florence remains a dangerous hurricane. It's closing in on the southeast coast. This hour, the center of the hurricane is located less than 400 miles offshore approaching the North Carolina and South Carolina coast, remains a very dangerous hurricane, category 3 on the scale at this time with winds of about 120 miles per hour. Don't think there'll be much change in terms of intensity over the next day or two, likely to approach the coast late Thursday into Friday with winds near that strength. Because of those winds, we're expecting a very high storm surge. As the center of the storm approaches the coast, strong winds will blow on shore, pushing water ashore, and that would mean a storm surge of -- as high as 9 to 13 feet. That's an innovation. Depth over normally dry water along portions of the North Carolina coast and up some of the rivers as well with somewhat lower values but still very dangerous all the way down into South Carolina and up to near the Virginia border. So there is a storm surge warning along the coast now for life-threatening storm surge. And this will be one of the key hazards for this hurricane. We expect that everyone who needs to prepare has -- is in the process of doing so or is completed doing so, and is following the recommendations of local officials, including evacuations as necessary. You also expect that the hurricane will slow down in its forward speed as it approaches the coast. That's bad news because not only does it prolong the wind and the storm surge along the coast, but it also allows the storm to dump more and more rainfall over land. And so we have a very large area of rainfall, total is expected of 5 to 10 inches or more, including areas that could see 20 inches, locally isolated spot to 40 inches. So we're expecting flooding along the coast from storm surge, the potential destructive winds of the coast, and then significant in-land flooding from rainfall. And this is a big risk coming into the next couple of days. The hazards will be increasing. The conditions will be deteriorating tomorrow. utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Hello, everybody and welcome to "The Five." Massive Hurricane Florence is set to slam into the Carolinas, potentially causing catastrophic damage, and somehow it's now President Trump's fault. The Washington Post out with an op-ed titled, another hurricane is about to batter our coast. Trump is complicit. According to the post, because President Trump doesn't bend over backwards to support climate change, he's now to blame. And I go to our resident climate change expert, Greg Gutfeld.

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: This always drives me crazy. OK, I'll start with two facts and then have an overall assessment of the situation.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan, close your ears, he's going to talk facts now.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: OK. So from 1915 to 1965, that's 51 years, that there are 19 major hurricanes. Now, if you go 51 years from there, 1966 to 2016, you've only had seven. So that's 37 percent as frequent. So if there's rising climate change and fewer of these major hurricanes, there goes your theory. But there is something -- you know, there's an increase in damage over time with these hurricanes. But that's not due to the storm intensity, it's because we're increasing infrastructure in coastal areas, so you can blame -- not global warming, but you can blame the builders for building in areas where there're storms. But I will say this to be fair because I know Juan disagree with me, the jury is probably still out on this stuff. It's going to take time to look at everything. The big problem is, is what I call the Trump floater. You know when you go to a bar and you order like a whiskey with a Bailey's floater or a Meyer's floater, every story is now a drink. Every story is a drink with a Trump floater. So it's like whether -- whether it's about -- like yesterday, 9/11, or hurricanes, or any kind of event, psychological disorders, depression.

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Can't sleep.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You can't sleep, it's Trump. So everything now has a Trump angle. Everything is a drink with a Trump floater and it's because people and the media have Trump on the brain and they're using that instead of their brain.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Why are all your analogies about bars and bathrooms?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: One always leads to the other.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's true. That's true. I came prepared. And I'm going to address you as Mr. Williams, because I found out how old you are, Juan. And I knew this was going to be very statistical type of segment. I brought a chart. Can we see the chart, please, in the control room? Look at this chart. America, the largest decline in co2 emissions in the world. Look at us all the way up the top. We're reducing our co2. And countries like China, the European Union. Canada, they're increasing their co2. So first year of the Trump presidency, co2 is down. Now, Juan, explained that one.

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Maybe you kept your mouth shut in the hot air, you know, didn't get out. But I will say this, you have us as the number one emitter of these gases, and you say we make some steps to pull back and, therefore, everybody else is to blame? I don't get it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, we're decreasing our co2.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, we're decreasing, and we should be.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: . and China, and India, and the E.U. are increasing there.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, because they have an increasing base of middle-class people, factories, and the like. They're still gaining in middle class. We're an establishes economy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The E.U. is gaining a middle class?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: They are -- not the E.U., but China, a lot of what they call the brick nation, you know, Brazil, India, they're building up, Jesse. So the idea is that the United States, as a successful economy with a large middle class, would set an example about the need for reducing co2.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And we are.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, we're not.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's why those statistics are what they are, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Here's what the Washington Post editorial board said. Guess who has just sign legislation to allow the expansion of methane gas in our released in our country? Donald Trump. Donald Trump and Republican orthodoxy has become, oh, we're the contraries. We don't believe these scientists. We don't believe any of this about increasing temperatures. And, Greg, there've been increasing temperatures over the last dozen years in the world.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, it's increasing temperature under my collar because you're making me very angry, Mr. Williams.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: There you go.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Jedediah?

utterances.speaker: JEDEDIAH BILA, GUEST CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: The implication is that the United States should take measures which often, frankly, are job killing measures. It's hundreds of thousands of people in this country lose their jobs because it hurts energy production. And these other sources of energy production are not yet ready to roll and compete with coal and otherwise. And other countries just get to do nothing, and why would we help them.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, no. Well, you're thinking.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: But that was what the Paris accord was about.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, no, it wasn't. And I think.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: . is a little off there, because the reality is that now alternative energy development has produced more jobs than -- let's say, coal mining.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, year, there's tons of windmill jobs out there, Juan.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They're backed by power stations.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right. Dana, let's get some facts here. This was about Donald Trump and pre-blaming him for the hurricane. I mean, it's used to be the hurricane comes and then they attack him. Now, they're.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, during President Obama's administration, Hurricane Sandy was blamed on Republicans as well. Republicans are always blamed for hurricanes. I talked to Charlie Hurt, yesterday, one of our Fox News contributor, he lives in the path of the hurricane and he said that people there are still talking about Hurricane Camille from 1969, when they had -- it was a terrible hurricane and that was before these rises. I do think that America plays an important role here, and that is because we're innovative and we have a growing economy right now, and that means you can invest in new technology so that you can get to the point that Jedediah was making which is, can we continue to figure out a way to decrease them. I would say from a political standpoint, the Republican Party could stand to talk about this a little bit more. They have a good position that they -- you know, you're going to lose an entire younger generation if you don't try to talk to them about this.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You can't win. You can't win.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, you can just not try.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The thing is, right now, what's happening is that liberals, the left, the liberals, they replaced global warming with Trump. It used to be that global warming cause more shark attacks and depression, but now they've just said no, Trump causes everything bad. And so, now we have to do our best to somehow reduce the amount of Trump in the atmosphere.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: You can support innovation. I think that's a great idea. But the problem is.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: But the problem is that they want -- first of all, the United States can't do this by ourselves. If we do great things when it comes to other energy sources and the rest of the world doesn't follow suit, it's not going to accomplish anything. And also, if these other areas are not ready to compete with coal, I'm all for it. I'm all for innovations, but if they're not ready you can't kill one industry, and all these people have nowhere to go, nowhere to work. So that's why the free market exists.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Remember when Hillary Clinton said to the coal miners, you know, we can help you move on, find new kind of jobs. It was, oh.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: He also said we're going to put you out of business.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They put her out of business.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: What we want to do is help people move on. But to your point, it sounded like you're making the case for the Paris climate deal because.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I know.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: . that locks in other countries to make commensurate sacrifices.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think you need to re-read the accords.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And the methane piece is a little bit more complicated than how Juan described it. We have to tease.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Tell me about it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right. And I think the most important thing is whatever shoes Melania wear to the hurricane ravage states, they better not be too expensive because she's going to get attacked. Democrats completely silent after yet another left-wing political attack. Greg's on it next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: As we hear the media complain about Trump's blunt rhetoric, it pays to see their response when violence follows their rhetoric. One man just tried to stab a Republican candidate as the fiend allegedly cursed Trump. This comes as yet another Broadway star pleads for the president's death:

utterances.speaker: CAROLE COOK, ACTRESS
utterances.utterance: Where is John Wilkes Booth when you need him, right? Will I be on an enemies list? Oh, god, I hope so.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, Johnny Depp looks terrible.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Cut back on the rum.

utterances.speaker: Now this comes as the cheerleader of confrontation brags about threatening Trump supporters all the time. You saw it
REP. MAXINE WATERS, D-CALIF.
utterances.utterance: I did not threaten his constituents, his supporters. I do that all the time, but I didn't do it that time.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Now the media will call this cause and effect, but since it's a liberal, it's just a coincidence. Yes, all this violent anti-Trump rhetoric has absolutely nothing to do with actually harm that follows. How stupid of us to think of that. If only we had an actual expert, someone who knows firsthand what left-wing political violence looks like:

utterances.speaker: REP. STEVE SCALISE, R-LA.
utterances.utterance: They need to be denouncing that kind of activity. There's no place for it. If somebody on the right was doing it, we'd be vocally denouncing it. They need to be denouncing that on the left.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Remember him? Now his words probably won't matter as much these days because most victims now are just those with wounded feelings because that's what we care about. We hear a lot about Trump's rhetoric as though it's worse than violent deeds, this after four decades of incendiary words and deeds churning from the left. Guys like Bill Ayers, the left-wing bomber who just retired from a university that you pay for. On 9/11, he was quoted in the New York Times saying, I don't regret setting bombs, I feel we didn't do enough. Why do I get the sense there are more and more people, 17 years later, who might agree with them? It's the business of demonization and it seems to be booming. Just ask Scalise. Indeed, Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's like the kicker.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, you like the kicker. The thing is, there's never really a follow-up on these things if it's a right -- if it's not a righty.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: it's a one-off. It's a isolated incident.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's just something (INAUDIBLE) the right tends to be a trend and that is extremely frustrating.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It is frustrating. It seems, Juan, that the media and Democrats denounce violence when it suits them. And I place you in that camp.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think it's Trump, by the way. When the right wing was all about beating up people at Trump rallies and I'm like, what did Trump say? He said, you know what, I don't endorse it but these people have tremendous passion.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Nothing has ever happened?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Nothing has ever happened? how about I'd like to punch him in the face says Trump? How about.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: . in the good old days, we knock the crap out.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Words, words.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So these words.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm talking about deeds.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, what about Charlottesville? You still want to talk about deeds?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Wait, so Trump cause that too?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: There's enough of that to go around.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's what I'm saying.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You think you can play that game.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'm not playing any game.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You are.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'm just saying Scalise deserves all our sympathies. And he has grounds to speak on this with great authority given the suffering that he went through. But I'm just saying it strikes me that when Maxine Waters, and we've seen this tape a hundred times now on Fox, I guess we like it, but when Maxine Waters said it's OK to confront people -- people say, oh, that's violence. That's not the kind of violence we're seeing at Trump rallies.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's funny because you just admitted she actually does threaten people all the time, just not in that particular incident.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, we're talking about, like, what happened with Sarah Huckabee Sanders.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's OK to harass people.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, no, no, to confront people and say, hey, I don't like what you're doing. We're Americans. We have a right to say that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: In a world where feelings matter, unless you're Republican. You know, I think Maxine's sin, Jedediah, is that she's promoting everything but democracy. She's not saying vote, like, go out and vote. She's saying impeach, which is essentially saying overthrow.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Yeah, she's saying, basically, bully and use the media and use everything to -- when the Democrat process that -- he got elected. He's everybody's president. I keep hearing liberal say, oh, he's not my president. He's everybody's president. And the media's selective coverage, I always think back to the tea party rallies that I went to all the time, and how the media was scouring those crowds looking for violence, looking for a signs that they could say was inciting violence. And then that same media ignored the same violence going on at Occupy Wall Street. People were getting raped, and there were accusations of rapes in these tents in New York City and beyond. And the media's refusal -- they'll hold Trump to task for language that I'll agree in some cases is not good. But they won't hold people accountable for actual violence against people on the right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, Antifa.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Somehow the rhetoric matters to them more than the actual acts of violence, because it depends on where it comes from.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I understand why people act violent. Because if you have been taught for years that the other side is the oppressor and that you are the oppressed, it's not about being wrong or right. It's about being moral and immoral or evil. So the Republicans and conservatives will always be the target of violence, because they are seen as immoral or evil.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But because the ends justify the means.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And that's how they've been raised, and that's what they believe. And they're like infants. If they don't get their way, they will scream and they will punch. And I understand the frustration because Trump is winning and he rubs it in their face. And he pushes their buttons, and they're completely shut out of power on every level of the federal government.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Excuse me, Dr. Watters.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, Mr. Williams.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I believe that -- I believe, Doctor, you were raised by liberal parents.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And I turned out fine. I haven't punched you yet.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's right. You said, oh, they were raised to do this. Were you raised to be violent?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, I'm saying they've been conditioned. Because like we've discussed, Hollywood has done a lot of disgusting things, and Maxine Waters, as you know, they traffic in this type of violent rhetoric. And I'm not blaming these people for the actions of one deranged individual. I'm saying they're not condemning these people when it comes out. This man, who has Trump Derangement Syndrome, just tried to stab a Republican congressional candidate. And I haven't heard this once on the network news, anywhere outside of Fox News or the Internet. Where is the condemnation coming in from leadership in the Democratic Party, that says, "We don't condone this type of stuff"? I don't hear it at all. I hear crickets.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: The guy is nuts.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: But you're not blaming --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He's nuts. I agree.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: You're saying you're not blaming -- you're not blaming all those people.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm not blaming, but they need to take a stand and condemn this stuff.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: But folks on the left don't do that. They will -- one person will come out who happens to have a comment on their Facebook page that's pro- Trump, and now that it's all Trump supporters, all Republicans are violent. They don't give that same courtesy.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I just want to say that there's one practical thing that could be done. The Federal Election Commission could change the law to allow campaign contributions to be used for personal security. And if you are a member or you are a candidate, and you are concerned, you should be allowed to do that. It would be fully disclosed, and I know that that is a proposal in front of them now, and I think they should just go ahead and do it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's a good suggestion. Put that in your good suggestion journal.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I will. That's a good idea. And smoke it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And smoke it. Oh, my goodness, Dana. What's happened to her? Ever since they legalized it, she's not been the same.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: She sits next to you. You're a bad influence.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, no. Are you kidding me? I can't even keep up. Coming up, we're expecting an update on Hurricane Florence from President Trump. We'll bring it to you live. Plus, Nancy Pelosi bragging that Democrats have the midterms in the bag. Straight ahead.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: This is a Fox News alert. We're expecting President Trump to speak at any moment. He's set to give us an update on the government's response to Hurricane Florence. By the way, the storm has been downgraded to to a Category 3, but please understand, it's still extremely dangerous. We'll bring it to you live when the president begins. Party leaders on the Hill drawing battle lines, issuing bold warnings and predictions for the midterm elections. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell fully expecting a rough fight in several of the battleground states.

utterances.speaker: SENATE MAJORITY LEADER MITCH MCCONNELL, R-KY.
utterances.utterance: All of them, too close to call. And every one of them, like a knife fight in an alley. I hope when the smoke clears that we'll still have a majority in the Senate.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi again expressing confidence that her party will won the House, and she's going to be elected speaker.

utterances.speaker: HOUSE MINORITY LEADER NANCY PELOSI, D-CALIF.
utterances.utterance: I feel very comfortable about the support that I have in the caucus. And that I will be the speaker of the House.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Dana, give us your sense of what's going on.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, I think that this is typical, right? So if you are the challenger, like Nancy Pelosi is, you want to express confidence and get people out there, motivate them to get out there. If you are McConnell and you're in -- on the defensive position, you want to say, "Well, it looks tough, and I hope everyone's going to give us a lot more money." And basically, McConnell is usually like that, too, right? He under-promises and over-delivers. That's his goal. But it is interesting that now Senator McConnell and his team is going to have to go into Texas and try to help Senator Ted Cruz to make sure that he can win that race. And that is a place where Republicans should not have to be spending money. But it's important enough that they are committed to doing it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Boy, can you believe that McConnell has to bail out Ted Cruz?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, they're best friends, I think.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: They are now.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I heard McConnell is doing something really cagey, which I expect. He's keeping the Senate open for the entire month of October to prevent all the Democratic senators from going to campaign, which is smart. And I think they'll keep the Senate and the House. It's really dicey. The congressional generic ballot has really trended towards the left ever since the Manafort and the Cohen news dropped in August. You saw that trend really spike at that moment, and it really energized the left and it really depressed the right. There's a lot of wild cards out there. George W. Bush is coming back, and he's starting to raise money. Trump is getting in there, and he's going to campaign hard. And then the only thing left is the economy, and the economy is ripping right now.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Blue-collar wages are through the roof. There's -- the stock market is back to 26,000. And gas price still below $3 a gallon. So things are looking good on that front. Who knows what's going to happen?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Jedediah, I think part of the amazement that people have is that places like Indiana --

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- which is a red state. Mike Pence, the vice president, from Indiana. And you have a Democrat incumbent there, Joe Donnelly. But right now it looks like a toss-up.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: I know.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And then you -- let's look at some other states. Montana, you know, Heidi Heitkamp looks like -- Jon Tester. I should say. Looks like a toss-up. Missouri.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Who thought that Democrats could hold these red --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But they haven't had the ads spent against them yet.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Yes, that's true.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Wait till that Coke money starts flowing in.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That would be -- that would be -- (UNINTELLIGIBLE) with an "H." Crazy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: With a "K."

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: You have a point, though, because you would never think --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Not cocaine, Mitch.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: -- that they'd have to fight in places -- it is an indication that places that -- that typically many would think would be a guarantee is not a guarantee. I do think Nancy Pelosi is a nightmare for Democrats, though. She's very polarizing. People in swing districts really can't stand her. A lot of Democrats on the ballot are already saying, "We're not aligning ourselves with her." And I think -- I think it's a bad move. I mean, she's part of an old regime, so to speak. I think they need some new blood in there. And if you have people on the fence, likely to vote, as you say, in all these places that are very red that may flip and may say, as a rejection of Trump, "We're going to vote for a Democrat," Nancy Pelosi is being used in all these Republican attack ads. And they're saying, "Listen, you don't want to go over there." So I don't know. But it's not right now, but it could. And I don't think she's very good for the left.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So Greg, I want to pick up on Jedediah's point with you, that, you know, you look at a situation where you want to encourage Republicans to go to the polls.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I saw that Kevin McCarthy, the whip, said, "Oh, Nancy Pelosi should scare people." Is that going to work?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, she could do it pretty easily. You know, these races are closer than Michael Moore's thighs.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Or about to eat dinner.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You have to prepare for the midterms the way you prepare for a hurricane. That means you've got to be prepared for the worst. And I think, you know, you go by history, the party of the incumbent always loses, because they don't see much of -- to win, which is a mistake on their part. And then the party that is out of power has nothing to lose and everything to gain, so you've got to prepare for that. I am looking forward to Pelosi back in the saddle, because I imagine our show will be written by 11 a.m. And I can head to the sauna, because we'll have two Pelosi blocks every day.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm excited.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: She will be the Wicked Witch of the West.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. Of "The Five."

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And she's coming in on a broom on top of the Hurricane Florence.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Uh-oh.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And we can go to Rick Reichmuth, and he'll say, "And there's Pelosi."

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You have a wild imagination, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: All right. Stay right there. Wild Card Wednesday up next on "The Five."

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I love this.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right. It's time now for "Wild Card Wednesday." All right. We each picked a topic that's not in the show and put them in this hat. None of us knows the stories each other selected. So up first, let's see if I get made fun of today. All right. Survey shows Americans are willing to go into debt for new iPhones. Eleven percent of Americans would be willing to go into debt. Announced today that phones range now from $750 all the way to 15 -- well, $1,400. That's a lot of money. Who's was this?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: This was mine.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And today the new iPhone comes out. Supposed to have a larger screen than ever, Dana. But it's the price, the price that's really shocking, because if you're going to pay $1,500 for an iPhone, basically now, we already know that there's a big line of demarcation in American society that says you can tell the rich from the poor by who owns an iPhone. Gregory is nodding, and so you know I'm right, Dana. Thank you, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't talk to anybody who doesn't own an iPhone.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK. Is that right? Oh, my gosh.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Actually, I don't talk to anybody.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, they don't talk to you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I know.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Put your microphone back on.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Would you go into debt for an iPhone?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm already in debt, Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: In debt to me.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK. Yes, no, I would not. I don't think I need it, and I use the flip phone still.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: From the late '90s.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: The Jitterbug?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It does as good of a job as the iPhone.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It is interesting. You've just written -- your new book is coming out soon.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: "#DoNotDisturb."

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And this doesn't surprise you that people would be willing.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: No, because people get addicted. And then you also want to fit in. It becomes the trendy new thing.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But also, want to take pictures.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Just like technology.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It also becomes your office. If you have one of these and you are an entrepreneur, you don't even need an office. You can work wherever you want.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Old models are good.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The reason why it's important is because it's supplementing your brain. This is -- people talk about putting stuff in your head. Everything is here. You've got the Bible. You've got every Shakespearean work. You've got everything you could ever have here. You -- this is your brain now. It is your external drive.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Worth every penny, worth every penny.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And I don't know my parents' phone number.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I do.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But you know --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Watch what you say about my mother!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, it was your dad.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I'm going to give you a tip. I'm going to give you a tip. Print out your contact list once a year. Because then, if something goes down, and you have a cyber-attack or something, you will have the phone numbers.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's another good idea.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Totally good idea.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Thank you. GreatIdeaJournal.com.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That was a good idea.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Dana, are you going to buy one?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I have an iPhone.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm bored by -- get the next --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: The next one is it's rude to wait more than 20 minutes to reply to a text, Google research. People think it's rude to wait.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: If you wait 20 minutes, people get rude. This isn't the one I chose. I mean, come on.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: That's the one I chose.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Really?

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Why did you choose it?

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Yes, because people are going insane. I have friends -- I have a friend who's dating a guy who, you know, she'll text him something and then if he doesn't answer, 10 minutes later, "Oh, I hate him."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You've got to let her wait at least 10 minutes. Twenty, 30.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: I mean, like, 20 minutes. People have jobs. They're doing other stuff. But because we're all like this, the assumption is that you're going to answer right away. Everybody's lost their minds.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: If you don't answer me immediately, you are dead to me.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: You don't answer me immediately when I text you.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I have another one. Mark Wahlberg at 47 baffles fans as he shares his insane day schedule. Apparently, daily routine includes two major workouts that last more than an hour each, two showers, a cryochamber recovery, golf, business news, family time and prayer.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: This was my story.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Starts his day at 2:30 a.m. and goes to bed at 7:30 p.m. Is that true?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, according to Mark. And I did this for all the ladies in the control room who really wanted to see Mark with his shirt off. You're welcome. It's a day similar to mine. You know, you wake up, you pray. Then you eat breakfast. Then you do two workouts.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He's really put on weight. You know, his percentage of body fat is a little bit higher than mine.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: High BMI there.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: He's not on one of those low-carb diets.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Greg, this must be yours, then. Novelist who wrote about how to murder your husband is charged with --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Killing her husband.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's amazing.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, you know, it's great, because it goes against my theory that, if you want to kill somebody, write a book saying you're going to kill somebody, because when they interview you, you go, "What? I would write a book I'm going to kill my wife and then kill my wife? That's nuts!"

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That was a movie.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: With Sharon Stone.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Was it? I can't remember.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: This is a romance novelist. She wrote books about relationships, including one about a woman --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What was the famous movie with Michael Douglas and Sharon Stone? "Basic Instinct." That's the plot of "Basic Instinct."

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Oh, this is because --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's the only movie you've seen.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No, because you're going back and watching movies from the '90s.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Guilty as charged.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Guilty as charged. What do you think, Jedediah?

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: I mean, Greg's point is true, honestly, on that. That's a racy movie, "Basic Instinct."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It is, it is.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: One movie you've seen, and that's it?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Shocked my moral fiber.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right. They're asking me to tease. That was a great "Wild Card Wednesday." "One More Thing" is up next.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Time now for "One More Thing." We're still awaiting the president, but -- Jesse --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: There's Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You know, the Woodward interview and the Kerry interview went to your head, Dana. You know what? It's an ensemble cast. This is not "The Daily Briefing."

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I want to make sure we get this in before.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK, let's do this. Go.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's Greg Gutfeld's birthday.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Woo!

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So sorry, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Look what they got me.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's a plate of ribs and also --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Ribs.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- a bottle of -- there you go.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Awesome. I'll be drinking this on the way home.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Happy birthday.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Thank you. From the Edna Valley. Mmm, the Maverick. I like to think of myself as "The Five's" maverick. These ribs, by the way, are insane.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right. Forty looks good on you, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Thank you. Forty what?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You want me to read this for you?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Eat some of these, you guys. I'm not eating all of them.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No, no, no, I'm good.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Are you sure? Fox Nation is underway. It's an on-demand subscription-based service. You can see a lot of exclusive talent from some of the best people that you see on the air here. And they're going to be even zanier behind --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Seen here.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Are you serious?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Greg Gutfeld will be there.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Mine's called -- mine's called "Dana's Book Club."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Dana will be there. But you don't say what kind of books they are.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Go for zany.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's very, very zany. I think Tomi Lahren wanted to say a few things. Let's listen.

utterances.speaker: TOMI LAHREN, FOX NEWS

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right. I think you'll --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: She nailed that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- be able to watch every single "Watters' World" package I ever cut, all 300 of them --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's such a bad idea.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- at Fox Nation. We tweaked some of them for time.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: For time. That's very smart.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: "Wednesdays with Watters" tonight on Martha MacCallum's show, 7 p.m. Be there or be square. Greg is next.

utterances.utterance: I've got a podcast, it's up. It's, what, at FoxNewsPodcasts.com. It's with Dr. Michael Aronoff. We talk about nightmares, sleep, sleep terrors, lucid dreaming and why we think bad thoughts. It's very interesting.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I bet it's heavy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You won't find that on Fox Nation. Yet, anyway. Anyway, maybe you will. Who knows?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right. Juan.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm eating ribs. What do I care?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So how's this for symbolism, folks? Take a look at this video shot yesterday in Andover, Minnesota. Yes, that's an eagle, in case you couldn't make it out, perched on an extended ladder on the back of a fire truck that was there to honor victims of the 9/11 terror attacks' 17th anniversary, the tragedy yesterday. Fire chief Jerry Streich, who made the video, said the eagle landed there and stayed for so long he was able to get his phone out and capture the video. The eagle landed there just as the pair of fire trucks were suspending a giant American flag. "We couldn't have asked for anything more patriotic," the chief said. The Facebook video, by the way, has been viewed by more than three million folks and attracted endless well wishes. Looks like fate, huh?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Beautiful video. All right. Jedediah.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Well, a camera that was meant to catch intruders caught another little thief in the kitchen with paws and a tail.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Uh-oh.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: This German Shepherd was enticed and smelled warm peanut butter, which frankly, I understand why that was appealing. You can't -- now, this dog removes the aluminum foil first, then gets back up and eats pretty much all the stuff.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Was it a pie?

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Luckily, it was a dog-friendly treat. This made me very nervous, because some stuff dogs can't eat.

utterances.speaker: Watters
utterances.utterance: Oh!

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: He knocks it over and apparently ate at all. Does Jasper do this?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No, he does not do that. He does not do that. He's an angel. We have a little bit of time. What are you doing for your birthday?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, after I eat these ribs --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Can I have a rib?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Are you kidding? I'm done, because I've got to go to dinner after this. The wife and I are going to have a nice meal downtown somewhere. I would give the name, but I would hate to be mobbed by my -- my massive fan base in downtown New York. They see me, they go crazy. They rip out what's left of my hair, and then they proposition me right in front of my wife. It's embarrassing.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: What's your ideal meal for your birthday? You have that planned out?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, I was going to -- I was going to have ribs, but now that I've had ribs, I'm going to have to find something else.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: An appetizer next.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You ruined your appetite, basically.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I had three ribs. But I probably won't eat until 8 p.m., so I can have another meal.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You've got time.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'm thinking -- I'm thinking of fireworks on the Hudson in celebration of Greg's birthday.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Wouldn't that be nice?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And then I was thinking we could have, like, dancing people, because you can't have dancing girls. I didn't want to say that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You'd just have dancing people on -- you know, like clowns on those high stilts?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You're a strange man.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Wow, you're really being creative.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know, what would be great for my birthday? If everybody went and bought my book, "The Gutfeld Monologues."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Ohh.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Wouldn't that be nice? That would be a great gift for me.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That would be great.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Because I'm the one who matters today.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right. The birthday boy said it. Set your DVRs. Never miss an episode of "The Five." "Special Report" is up next -- Bret.
